name: Teaching Guide: Exploring Latin American Revolutionaries

affiliation.name: Lexington School District One, South Carolina

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Using the [map of colonies](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/901), describe the various geographic features that promoted and/or discouraged communication and unification in Latin America. What do you notice about the geography of cities highlighted on the map and the geography of battle sites?
2. After reading the biographical information about each of the leaders included in this set, draw comparisons between them with regard to their motivation for liberation and independence and their plans for the new nations they fought to free.
3. Read the [excerpt from J.R. Beard’s biography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/906). What are the major similarities between L’Ouverture and Napoleon Bonaparte? How were these two men different?
4. Look at the [portrait of Simón Bolívar](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/908) and the [image of a statue of Bolívar](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/910). What other figures throughout history have been clad in such a way? What do you think the artist’s intent was when choosing such attire? Look at other portraits in this set and analyze how each of the freedom fighters are depicted.

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text: Ask students to create a two-page spread for a children’s book depicting the “road to liberation” for Latin Americans. Students should include information about the four freedom fighters highlighted in this set: José de San Martin, Simón Bolívar, Toussaint L’Ouverture, and Miguel Hidalgo. Ask students to combine their stories using a road map or timeline suitable for a children’s book.
